org.gearvrf

Class GVRMaterial

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRMaterial
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GVRShaders

    public class GVRMaterial
extends GVRHybridObject
implements GVRShaders
    Encapsulates the data needed for shading, including textures and shader uniforms. You can have invisible scene objects: these have a location and a set of child objects. This can be useful, to move a set of scene objects as a unit, preserving their relative geometry. Invisible scene objects don't need any render data.

    Visible scene objects must have render data attached. Each GVRRenderData has a GL mesh that defines its geometry, and a GVRMaterial that defines its surface.

    Each GVRMaterial contains two main things:

    • The id of a shader, which is used to draw the mesh. See GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType and GVRContext.getMaterialShaderManager().
    • Data to pass to the shader. This usually - but not always - means a GVRTexture and can include other named values to pass to the shader.

    The simplest way to create a GVRMaterial is to call the constructor that takes only a GVRContext. Then you just setTexture() and you're ready to draw with the default shader, which simply drapes the texture over the mesh. 

     // for example
 GVRMaterial material = new GVRMaterial(gvrContext);
 material.setTexture("main_texture", texture);

      • setMainTexture

        public void setMainTexture(java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> texture)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaders
        Asynchronously bind a different texture to the main_texture shader uniform. Uses a background thread from the thread pool to wait for the Future.get() method; unless you are loading dozens of textures asynchronously, the extra overhead should be modest compared to the cost of loading a texture.
        Specified by:
        setMainTexture in interface GVRShaders
        Parameters:
        texture - A future texture, from one of the the GVRAssetLoader.loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource) methods

      • getColor

        public float[] getColor()
        Get the color uniform. By convention, some of the GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named color. With the default 'texture' shader, this allows you to modulate the texture with a color.
        Returns:
        The current vec3 color as a three-element array

        public void setColor(float r,
                     float g,
                     float b)
        Set the color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named color. With the default 'texture' shader, this allows you to modulate the texture with a color. Values are between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        r - Red
        g - Green
        b - Blue

      • getAmbientColor

        public float[] getAmbientColor()

        Returns:
        The current vec4 materialAmbientColor as a four-element array

      • setAmbientColor

        public void setAmbientColor(float r,
                            float g,
                            float b,
                            float a)
        Set the materialAmbientColor uniform for lighting. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec4 uniform named materialAmbientColor. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay ambient light color on top of the texture. Values are between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        r - Red
        g - Green
        b - Blue
        a - Alpha

      • getDiffuseColor

        Returns:
        The current vec4 materialDiffuseColor as a four-element array

      • setSpecularExponent

        public void setSpecularExponent(float exp)
        Set the materialSpecularExponent uniform for lighting. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a float uniform named materialSpecularExponent. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay specular light color on top of the texture. Values are between 0.0f and 128.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        exp - Specular exponent

      • getOpacity

        public float getOpacity()
        Get the opacity. This method returns the opacity uniform. The setOpacity() documentation explains what the opacity uniform does.
        Returns:
        The opacity uniform used to render this material

      • setOpacity

        public void setOpacity(float opacity)
        Set the opacity, in a complicated way. There are two things you need to know, how opacity is applied, and how opacity is implemented.

        First, GVRF does not sort by distance every object it can see, then draw from back to front. Rather, it sorts every object by render order, then draws the scene graph in traversal order. So, if you want to see a scene object through another scene object, you have to explicitly set the rendering order so that the translucent object draws after the opaque object. You can use any integer values you like, but GVRF supplies four standard values; the default value is GEOMETRY.

        Second, technically all this method does is set the opacity uniform. What this does depends on the actual shader. If you don't specify a shader (or you specify the GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Texture shader) setting opacity does exactly what you expect; you only have to worry about the render order. However, it is totally up to a custom shader whether or how it will handle opacity.

        Parameters:
        opacity - Value between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.

      • setLineWidth

        public void setLineWidth(float lineWidth)
        Sets the line width for line drawing. By default, the line width is 1. It is applied when the draw mode is GL_LINES, GL_LINE_STRIP or GL_LINE_LOOP.
        Parameters:
        lineWidth - new line width.
        See Also:
        GVRRenderData.setDrawMode(int)

      • getTextureNames

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getTextureNames()

        Returns:
        set of unique texture names.

      • setShaderFeatureSet

        public void setShaderFeatureSet(int featureSet)
        Set the feature set for pre-built shader's. Pre-built shader could be written to support all the properties of a material system with preprocessor macro to On/Off features. feature set would determine which properties are available for current model. Currently only Assimp shader has support for feature set.
        Parameters:
        featureSet - Feature set for this material.

      • getShaderFeatureSet

        public int getShaderFeatureSet()
        Get the feature set associated with this material.
        Returns:
        An integer representing the feature set.
